thread.title: Yamuna above danger mark in Delhi, relief camps set up; IMD predicts more rain for 4-5 days
thread.title_full: Yamuna above danger mark in Delhi, relief camps set up; IMD predicts more rain for 4-5 days

author: @CNBCTV18Live
title: Yamuna above danger mark in Delhi, relief camps set up; IMD predicts more rain for 4-5 days
text:
3 Min Read
(Photo Credit : Yamuna River flows above danger level mark in Delhi on August 28, 2025. A temple submerged as water level continues to rise. (PTI Images) )
The water level in the Yamuna River has been increasing continuously due to heavy rains in Delhi, and it crossed the danger mark of 205.33 metres on the night of Wednesday, August 27. Authorities set up relief camps to prepare for potential flood in the city.
The water level was recorded at 205.45 m at the Old Railway Bridge on Yamuna River on Thursday, August 28, officials said, reported news agency PTI.
The Central Water Commission advised the officials to take necessary action in their respective regions. The flood situation is being monitored continuously, they said.
The officials concerned also reasoned that the water level is rising due to "high volumes of water released from the Wazirabad and Hathnikund barrages every hour," as per PTI.
The Hathnikund barrage in Haryana is releasing around 36,536 cusecs of water while Wazirabad is releasing 58,290 cusecs of water every hour, according to the flood control department.
Read more:
It normally takes 48-50 hours for the water released from the barrages to reach Delhi.
Flood relief camps in Mayur Vihar
The authorities have ramped up efforts to mitigate the potential flood situation in the city, by setting up relief camps and making people aware about the safety precautions.
A flood relief camp has been set up in Delhi's Mayur Vihar by the District Magistrate.
"These tenants are set up for living... People living inside their homes near the river will come out and live in these tents when the flood comes," Ashok, a local resident was quoted as saying by news agency ANI.
The people are evacuated from the nearby areas of Yamuna at 206 m mark. The warning mark for the city is 204.5 m, while the danger mark is 205.33 m
IMD forecasts rains for next 4-5 days
The India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecast active monsoon conditions to prevail over Delhi during next four to five days.
Read more:
The IMD Delhi Cente said that the city is likely to witness a generally cloudy sky on August 28 with a possibility of very light to light rain along with thundershowers at a few places towards afternoon or evening.
There is a possibility of very light to light rain during subsequent five days, the IMD noted in its weather bulletin.
